query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Godi, Fiorenza, poi che se’ sì grande 2 che per mare e per terra batti l’ali, 3 e per lo ’nferno tuo nome si spande!
4 Tra li ladron trovai cinque cotali 5 tuoi cittadini onde mi ven vergogna, 6 e tu in grande orranza non ne sali.
query.result:
1 Rejoice, Florence, since you are so great 2 that you beat your wings over sea and land, 3 and your name spreads even through Hell!
4 Among the thieves I found five such 5 of your citizens that it shames me, 6 and you do not rise in great honor from it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
7 Ma se presso al mattin del ver si sogna, 8 tu sentirai, di qua da picciol tempo, 9 di quel che Prato, non ch’altri, t’agogna.
query.result: 7 But if one dreams of the truth near morning, 8 you will hear, before too long, 9 of what Prato, not to mention others, yearns for you.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 E se già fosse, non saria per tempo. 11 Così foss’ ei, da che pur esser dee! 12 ché più mi graverà, com’ più m’attempo.
query.result: 10 And if it were already so, it would not be too soon. 11 If only it were so, since it must be! 12 For it will weigh on me more the older I get.

13 We departed and climbed up the stairs 14 that the blind man had made earlier to descend, 15 my leader remounted and pulled me up;
16 and continuing on the solitary path, 17 among the splinters and boulders of the cliff 18 one could not make progress with one's foot without one's hand.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Allor mi dolsi, e ora mi ridoglio 20 quando drizzo la mente a ciò ch’io vidi, 21 e più lo ’ngegno affreno ch’i’ non soglio,
22 perché non corra che virtù nol guidi; 23 sì che, se stella bona o miglior cosa 24 m’ha dato ’l ben, ch’io stessi nol m’invidi.
query.result:
19 Then I grieved, and now I grieve again 20 when I turn my mind to what I saw, 21 and I restrain my intellect more than I am wont,
22 so that it does not run without virtue to guide it; 23 so that, if a good star or a better thing 24 has given me the good fortune that I have remained steadfast, I do not begrudge it to myself.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Quante ’l villan ch’al poggio si riposa, 26 nel tempo che colui che ’l mondo schiara 27 la faccia sua a noi tien meno ascosa,
28 come la mosca cede a la zanzara, 29 vede lucciole giù per la vallea, 30 forse colà dov’ e’ vendemmia e ara:
31 di tante fiamme tutta risplendea 32 l’ottava bolgia, sì com’ io m’accorsi 33 tosto che fui là ’ve ’l fondo parea.
query.result:
25 As many as the peasant who rests on the hillside, 26 at the time when he who illumines the world 27 keeps his face less hidden from us,
28 when the fly yields to the mosquito, 29 sees fireflies down in the valley, 30 perhaps where he harvests and ploughs:
31 with so many flames the eighth chasm was all resplendent, 32 as I realized 33 as soon as I was where the bottom appeared.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 E qual colui che si vengiò con li orsi 35 vide ’l carro d’Elia al dipartire, 36 quando i cavalli al cielo erti levorsi,
37 che nol potea sì con li occhi seguire, 38 ch’el vedesse altro che la fiamma sola, 39 sì come nuvoletta, in sù salire:
40 tal si move ciascuna per la gola 41 del fosso, ché nessuna mostra ’l furto, 42 e ogne fiamma un peccatore invola.
query.result:
34 And as he who took vengeance with the bears 35 saw Elijah's chariot at his departure, 36 when the horses rose straight up to heaven,
37 so that he could not follow it with his eyes, 38 so that he saw nothing but the flame alone, 39 like a little cloud, rising upwards:
40 so each one moves through the gullet 41 of the ditch, for none shows its theft, 42 and each flame steals a sinner.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 Io stava sovra ’l ponte a veder surto, 44 sì che s’io non avessi un ronchion preso, 45 caduto sarei giù sanz’ esser urto.
query.result: 43 I stood up on the bridge to watch, 44 so that if I had not grabbed a large branch, 45 I would have fallen down without being pushed.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 E ’l duca che mi vide tanto atteso, 47 disse: «Dentro dai fuochi son li spirti; 48 catun si fascia di quel ch’elli è inceso».

Please translate each line literally into English.
49 «Maestro mio», rispuos’ io, «per udirti 50 son io più certo; ma già m’era avviso 51 che così fosse, e già voleva dirti:
52 chi è ’n quel foco che vien sì diviso 53 di sopra, che par surger de la pira 54 dov’ Eteòcle col fratel fu miso?».
query.result:
49 "My master," I replied, "to hear you 50 makes me more certain; but I had already guessed 51 that it was so, and I wanted to ask you:
52 who is in that fire that comes so divided 53 above, that it seems to rise from the pyre 54 where Eteocles was placed with his brother?"

55 He replied to me: "Within there Ulysses and Diomedes are tormented, 56 and thus together 57 they go to vengeance as they did to wrath;
58 and within their flame there is lamentation 59 for the ambush of the horse that made the gate 60 from which the noble seed of the Romans issued forth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Piangevisi entro l’arte per che, morta, 62 Deïdamìa ancor si duol d’Achille, 63 e del Palladio pena vi si porta».
query.result: 61 Within there is weeping for the craftiness by which, though dead, 62 Deidamia still grieves for Achilles, 63 and punishment is borne there for the Palladium."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 «S’ei posson dentro da quelle faville 65 parlar», diss’ io, «maestro, assai ten priego 66 e ripriego, che ’l priego vaglia mille,
67 che non mi facci de l’attender niego 68 fin che la fiamma cornuta qua vegna; 69 vedi che del disio ver’ lei mi piego!».
query.result: 64 "If they can speak from within those flames," I said, "master, I beg you earnestly, 66 and beg you again, so that my begging may be worth a thousand, 67 that you do not refuse me the waiting 68 until the horned flame comes here; 69 see how I bend with desire toward it!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Ed elli a me: «La tua preghiera è degna 71 di molta loda, e io però l’accetto; 72 ma fa che la tua lingua si sostegna.

Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Lascia parlare a me, ch’i’ ho concetto 74 ciò che tu vuoi; ch’ei sarebbero schivi, 75 perch’ e’ fuor greci, forse del tuo detto».
query.result: 73 Let me speak, for I have understood 74 what you want; for they would be shy, 75 because they were Greeks, perhaps, of your speech."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Poi che la fiamma fu venuta quivi 77 dove parve al mio duca tempo e loco, 78 in questa forma lui parlare audivi:
79 «O voi che siete due dentro ad un foco, 80 s’io meritai di voi mentre ch’io vissi, 81 s’io meritai di voi assai o poco
82 quando nel mondo li alti versi scrissi, 83 non vi movete; ma l’un di voi dica 84 dove, per lui, perduto a morir gissi».
query.result:
76 After the flame had come to the place 77 where it seemed to my leader to be the right time and place, 78 I heard him speak in this manner:
79 "O you who are two within one fire, 80 if I deserved of you while I was alive, 81 if I deserved of you much or little
82 when I wrote the lofty verses in the world, 83 do not move; but let one of you tell 84 where, through him, you went lost to your death."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 Lo maggior corno de la fiamma antica 86 cominciò a crollarsi mormorando, 87 pur come quella cui vento affatica;
88 indi la cima qua e là menando, 89 come fosse la lingua che parlasse, 90 gittò voce di fuori e disse: «Quando
91 mi diparti’ da Circe, che sottrasse 92 me più d’un anno là presso a Gaeta, 93 prima che sì Enëa la nomasse,
94 né dolcezza di figlio, né la pieta 95 del vecchio padre, né ’l debito amore 96 lo qual dovea Penelopè far lieta,
97 vincer potero dentro a me l’ardore 98 ch’i’ ebbi a divenir del mondo esperto 99 e de li vizi umani e del valore;
100 ma misi me per l’alto mare aperto 101 sol con un legno e con quella compagna 102 picciola da la qual non fui diserto.

Please translate each line literally into English.
103 L’un lito e l’altro vidi infin la Spagna, 104 fin nel Morrocco, e l’isola d’i Sardi, 105 e l’altre che quel mare intorno bagna.
query.result: 103 I saw one shore and then the other as far as Spain, 104 as far as Morocco, and the island of Sardinia, 105 and the others that that sea bathes around.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Io e ’ compagni eravam vecchi e tardi 107 quando venimmo a quella foce stretta 108 dov’ Ercule segnò li suoi riguardi
109 acciò che l’uom più oltre non si metta; 110 da la man destra mi lasciai Sibilia, 111 da l’altra già m’avea lasciata Setta.
query.result:
106 I and my companions were old and slow 107 when we came to that narrow strait 108 where Hercules marked his boundaries
109 so that man should not go any further; 110 on my right hand I left Seville, 111 on the other I had already left Ceuta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 “O frati”, dissi “che per cento milia 113 perigli siete giunti a l’occidente, 114 a questa tanto picciola vigilia
115 d’i nostri sensi ch’è del rimanente 116 non vogliate negar l’esperïenza, 117 di retro al sol, del mondo sanza gente.
query.result:
112 "O brothers," I said, "who through a hundred thousand 113 perils have reached the west, 114 do not deny to this brief vigil
115 of our senses that remains 116 the experience of the uninhabited world, 117 following the sun."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Considerate la vostra semenza: 119 fatti non foste a viver come bruti, 120 ma per seguir virtute e canoscenza”.
query.result: 118 Consider your origin: 119 you were not made to live like brutes, 120 but to follow virtue and knowledge."

121 With this short speech I made my companions 122 so eager for the journey 123 that I could hardly have held them back afterwards;
124 and turning our stern to the morning, 125 we made wings of our oars for our mad flight, 126 always gaining on the left-hand side.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Tutte le stelle già de l’altro polo 128 vedea la notte, e ’l nostro tanto basso, 129 che non surgëa fuor del marin suolo.
query.result: 127 Night could already see all the stars of the other pole, 128 and ours so low 129 that it did not rise above the surface of the sea.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Cinque volte racceso e tante casso 131 lo lume era di sotto da la luna, 132 poi che ’ntrati eravam ne l’alto passo,
133 quando n’apparve una montagna, bruna 134 per la distanza, e parvemi alta tanto 135 quanto veduta non avëa alcuna.
query.result:
130 Five times the light beneath the moon had rekindled and as many times waned, 131 since we had entered the deep passage,
132 when a mountain appeared to us, dark 133 because of the distance, and it seemed to me as high 135 as I had never seen any.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
136 Noi ci allegrammo, e tosto tornò in pianto; 137 ché de la nova terra un turbo nacque 138 e percosse del legno il primo canto.

Please translate each line literally into English.
139 Tre volte il fé girar con tutte l’acque; 140 a la quarta levar la poppa in suso 141 e la prora ire in giù, com’ altrui piacque,
142 infin che ’l mar fu sovra noi richiuso».
query.result:
139 Three times it made it whirl with all the waters; 140 at the fourth, it lifted the stern into the air 141 and sent the prow down, as pleased another,
142 until the sea closed over us."
